name.text: 39.1.6.1 Applications of the Normal Distribution - Simple Example

questiontext.text:
Applications of the Normal Distribution

We have, in the previous subsection, noted that the probability density function of a normal distribution \(X\) is \[y=\dfrac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{\frac{-(x-\mu )^2}{2\sigma^2}}\] This curve is always ‘ bell-shaped’ with the centre of the bell located at the value of \(\mu\). The height of the bell is controlled by the value of \(\sigma\). See the Figure below.


Figure: the Probability Density Function of the Normal Distribution

We now show, by example, how probabilities relating to a general normal distribution \(X\) are determined. We will see that being able to calculate the probabilities of a standard normal distribution \(Z\) is crucial in this respect.

Example

Given that the variate \(X\) follows the normal distribution \(X\sim N(151,15^2)\), calculate:

  1. \(\text{P}(120\le X\le 155)\)
  2. \(\text{P}(X\ge 185)\)

Solution

The transformation used in this problem is \(Z=\dfrac{X-\mu}{\sigma}=\dfrac{X-151}{15}\)

  1. \(\text{P}(120\le X\le 155)=\text{P}\left(\dfrac{120-151}{15}\le Z\le \dfrac{155-151}{15}\right)\)

    \(\phantom{\text{P555}}=\text{P}(-2.07\le Z\le 0.27)\)

    \(\phantom{\text{P}(120\le)}=0.4808+0.1064=0.5872\)

  2. \(\text{P}(X\ge 185)=\text{P}\left(Z\ge \dfrac{185-151}{15}\right)\)

    \(\phantom{\text{P55}}=\text{P}( Z\ge 2.27)\)

    \(\phantom{\text{P}(X\ge 1855)}=0.5-0.4884=0.0116\)

 

We note that, as for any continuous random variable, we can only calculate the probability that

\(\quad\bullet\quad\) \(X\) lies between two given values;

\(\quad\bullet\quad\) \(X\) is greater than a given value;

\(\quad\bullet\quad\) \(X\) is less that a given value,

rather than for individual values.
